subject: polity
title: Directive Principles of State Policy - Staircase Model
description: Climb through the categories of DPSPs using an interactive staircase. Each step represents a category of directive principles that guide State policy-making.

keyPoints: **Art 36**: 'State' has same meaning as in Art 12 (for Part III - FRs)
**Art 37**: DPSPs are **not justiciable** (cannot be enforced through courts) BUT **fundamental in governance**
DPSPs are **positive obligations** on State to achieve socio-economic democracy
Guide State in making laws and policies
distinction: **FRs are negative** (State shall NOT do); **DPSPs are positive** (State shall do)
**FRs are justiciable** (enforceable in court); **DPSPs are non-justiciable** (not enforceable)
**FRs impose limitations** on State; **DPSPs give directions** to State
significance: Balance individual liberty (FRs) with social welfare (DPSPs)
Dr. Ambedkar: '*Novel feature of Indian Constitution*'
content.examTips: **Art 37 most important**: DPSPs non-justiciable but fundamental in governance. Remember distinction from FRs: FRs negative & justiciable; DPSPs positive & non-justiciable.

keyPoints: **Art 38(1)**: State to promote welfare through **social order** ensuring justice (social, economic, political)
**Art 38(2)**: Minimize inequalities in income, status, facilities, opportunities
**Art 39**: Principles of policy including:
• **39(a)**: Adequate livelihood for men and women
• **39(b)**: Ownership & control of material resources for common good (socialism)
• **39(c)**: Prevent concentration of wealth
• **39(d)**: Equal pay for equal work for both men and women
• **39(e)**: Protection of health and strength of workers, children not abused
• **39(f)**: Childhood and youth protected against exploitation
**Art 46**: Promote educational and economic interests of **SCs, STs, and weaker sections**; protect from social injustice and exploitation
**Art 47**: Raise **level of nutrition, standard of living**, improve **public health**; prohibit intoxicating drinks and harmful drugs (except medicinal)
content.examTips: **Most important cluster**: Art 39 has 6 sub-clauses (a-f) - frequently asked in exams. 39(b) basis for nationalization. 39(d) equal pay principle. Art 46 protects SCs/STs.

keyPoints: **Art 39** (already covered in Step 2, but crucial for economic policy)
**Art 41**: Right to work, education, and public assistance in cases of unemployment, old age, sickness, disablement
**Art 42**: Provision for **just and humane conditions of work** and **maternity relief**
**Art 43**: Secure **living wage**, decent standard of life, social and cultural opportunities for workers; promote **cottage industries** in rural areas
**Art 43A**: **Participation of workers in management** of industries (added by 42nd Amendment 1976)
significance: Promote full employment and social security
content.examTips: **Art 43A added by 42nd Amendment 1976** - workers in management. Art 41 right to work implemented through MGNREGA. Art 42 maternity relief is now FR for organized sector (Maternity Benefit Act).

keyPoints: **Art 40**: Organize **village panchayats** and give them powers to function as units of self-government
**Art 43**: Promote **cottage industries** on individual or cooperative basis in rural areas (already in Step 3)
**Art 46**: Promote interests of weaker sections, especially **SCs and STs** (social justice aspect)
**Art 47**: Raise nutrition, standard of living; improve public health; **prohibit intoxicating drinks** (prohibition is Gandhian ideal)
**Art 48**: Organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern lines; **prohibit slaughter of cows, calves, and other milch/draught cattle**
significance: Reflect Gandhi's vision of **Gram Swaraj** (village self-rule)
Protection of cattle (cultural and agricultural importance)
implementation: **73rd Amendment 1992** - Constitutional status to Panchayati Raj (Art 40)
content.examTips: **Gandhian DPSPs**: Art 40 (Panchayats - implemented via 73rd Amendment), Art 43 (cottage industries), Art 47 (prohibition), Art 48 (cow protection). Reflect Gandhi's rural focus.
content.caDebates: Constituent Assembly debated cow slaughter extensively. Dr. Ambedkar clarified it's for **economic reasons** (draught/milch cattle), not religious. Article carefully worded to include scientific breeding.

keyPoints: **Art 44**: State shall secure **Uniform Civil Code (UCC)** for citizens throughout India
**Art 49**: Protect **monuments, places, objects of national importance** (historical, artistic)
**Art 50**: Separate **judiciary from executive** in public services of State
significance: **UCC (Art 44)** - Most debated DPSP; aims to replace personal laws with common civil code
**Art 50** - Judicial independence at grassroots (separation of powers)
implementation: **Goa** has UCC (inherited from Portuguese Civil Code) - only Indian state with UCC
**Separation of judiciary-executive** mostly achieved in states through judicial orders
challenges: **UCC remains unimplemented** at national level - politically sensitive (personal laws of different religions)
**Shah Bano case (1985)** highlighted need for UCC; but political backlash led to Muslim Women Act 1986
Art 44 non-justiciable - courts cannot force implementation
content.examTips: **Art 44 UCC** - Most controversial DPSP. Only Goa has UCC. Remember Shah Bano case. **Art 50 separation** - Tamilnadu implemented first. Art 49 for heritage protection (ASI role).

keyPoints: **Art 48A**: State shall protect and improve **environment** and safeguard **forests and wildlife** (added by 42nd Amendment 1976)
Added along with Art 51A(g) which makes environment protection a **Fundamental Duty**
significance: Recognition of environmental concerns in Constitution
Judicial activism made environment part of Art 21 (right to healthy environment)
implementation: **Judicial pronouncements** - MC Mehta cases on Ganga pollution, vehicular pollution, etc.
content.examTips: **Added by 42nd Amendment 1976** along with Art 51A(g) (Fundamental Duty). Judiciary linked environment to Art 21. NGT (2010) adjudicates environmental disputes.

keyPoints: **Art 51**: State shall endeavor to:
• **51(a)**: Promote **international peace and security**
• **51(b)**: Maintain **just and honorable relations** between nations
• **51(c)**: Foster respect for **international law** and treaty obligations
• **51(d)**: Encourage settlement of international disputes by **arbitration**
implementation: Membership in **ICJ, WTO, WHO, ILO** etc.
Settlement of disputes through dialogue (e.g., India-Bangladesh maritime boundary via arbitration)
content.examTips: **Art 51** guides foreign policy. Remember 4 sub-clauses: peace, honorable relations, international law, arbitration. Panchsheel principles operationalize Art 51.

data.summary: **DPSPs (Part IV, Art 36-51)** are non-justiciable directives to State for socio-economic governance. **7 categories**: (1) Foundation (36-37), (2) Social Justice (38-39, 46-47), (3) Economic (39, 41-43, 43A), (4) Gandhian (40, 43, 46-48), (5) Administrative (44, 49-50), (6) Environmental (48A), (7) International (51). **Key exam points**: Art 37 (non-justiciable), Art 39 (6 clauses), Art 44 (UCC - unimplemented except Goa), Art 48A (42nd Amendment), Art 43A (42nd Amendment). **DPSP vs FR**: DPSPs positive obligations, non-justiciable, society-centric vs FRs negative rights, justiciable, individual-centric. Both complementary - FRs means, DPSPs ends.
